keywords.term: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland

div1.p: O. H. LAMOREUX COURT STENOGRAPHER NOME, ALASKA
IN THE DISTRICT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION. BEFORE Hon. ROBERT W. McCLELLAND, Esq., COMMISSIONER OF THE UNITED STATES.
In re THE EXTRADITION OF FLETCHER DECKER.
J U D G M E N T.

This cause coming on for hearing upon the 24th day of August, 1921, upon the complaint of Thomas Waters, and the amended complaint of H. H. L. Murray, British Vice Counsl, for the extradition at Fletcher Decker, the said Fletcher Decker appearing at this hearing, having been theretofore admitted to bail, thereupon the evidence of G. H. L. Murray, Claude Ficklin, Thomas Waters and Sydney Brown Woods was taken in shorthand, and documentary evidence was introduced in evidence as Exhibit "A", and from such evidence so introduced I find, that Fletcher Decker, in the Province of Saskatchewan, in the Dominion of Canada, on or about the 15th day of November, 1913, near Wiwa Hill Post Office, he, the said Fletcher Decker then and there being, did then and there take, steal and carry away about three hundred bushels of flax, the property of Claude Ficklin, and was thereby guilty of theft.

I further find, that said offense is an extra- dictable offense under Section 5270 of the Revised Statutues of the United States as amended by an act of Congress approved June 6, 1900, entitled "An Act amending Section 5270 of the Revised Statutes of the United States", and the extradition convention between the United States
O. H. LAMOREUX COURT STENOGRAPHER NOME, ALASKA

of America and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, proclaimed by the President of the United States the 25th day of March 1890, supplementary to the Tenth Article of the Treaty concluded between the same high contracting parties on the 9th day of August, 1842.
And I further find, that the said Fletcher Decker, produced in this proceeding, is the same identical
